vectorData.altText: 3. Disorders of gait and balance can occur with damage to the _____________ cerebellar peduncle.
That’s right!  The inferior cerebellar peduncle influences balance and gait through the ipsilateral vestibulospinal and reticulospinal pathways respectively.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

The cerebellum coordinates balance, posture and stereotyped movements such as locomotion, which involve axial      and proximal limb musculature. This function is dependent on three main sources of sensory input: proprioceptive, vestibular and visual. 
The portions of the cerebellum involved in using this input to coordinate these types of activities are the flocculus, nodule, vermis and adjacent paravermal regions, i.e. midline structures, and their associated deep nuclei. 
The output from these portions of the cerebellum pass through the inferior cerebellar peduncle. It influences balance and gait primarily through the ipsilateral vestibulospinal and reticulospinal pathways, respectively.
Thus midline lesions of the cerebellum, or lesions of the inferior cerebellar peduncle, lead to disorders of balance and gait. 
Output from these regions of the cerebellum, also passing through the inferior cerebellar peduncle, coordinates the movement of the eye in the orbit with that of the neck and head via the medial longitudinal fasciculus. An example of this is when you shake your head “no”, but maintain your gaze straight ahead. Thus, another sign of such lesions is ataxic eye movements (i.e. ocular dysmetria).
